content: The "Commission on Americans Living Abroad Act" establishes a commission known as the "Commission on Americans Living Abroad" with defined membership. The Commission on Americans Living Abroad Act establishes a 15-member Commission appointed by the President, with members recommended by various leaders in the House and Senate. The Commission on Americans Living Abroad Act establishes a 15-member Commission appointed by the President, with members recommended by various leaders in the House and Senate. The Commission members must meet qualifications such as limits on officers or employees of the United States, restrictions on political party affiliation, and expertise related to the matters to be studied by the Commission. Members of the Commission on Americans Living Abroad Act must meet specific qualifications, including not being officers or employees of the United States. They should have lived in a foreign country for at least one year, be part of organizations representing US citizens abroad, or have relevant experience. Appointments are for the life of the Commission, vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers. The first meeting must occur within 60 days of a specified date. The Commission on Americans Living Abroad Act requires the Commission to hold its first meeting within 60 days of all members being appointed. The Chairperson is selected by the President from among the members, and a majority of members constitute a quorum for meetings. SEC. 4. DUTIES. The Commission on Americans Living Abroad Act outlines the duties of the Commission. The Commission shall conduct a study on how Federal laws and policies affect US citizens living abroad, including financial reporting requirements and access to financial institutions. The curr_chunk discusses federal requirements for US citizens living abroad, including tax compliance, financial institution regulations, citizenship for family members, and voting in US elections. The curr_chunk focuses on the processes for US citizens living abroad to interact with federal programs, obtain federal education loans, and improve collaboration between federal agencies serving expatriates. The Commission shall consult organizations representing US citizens living abroad and submit reports to the President, Congress, and relevant federal agencies with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions. An update will be provided one year after the initial report. The Commission will submit reports to the President, Congress, and federal agencies with recommendations for legislative and administrative actions, including any actions taken by agency heads. The Commission has powers to submit reports with recommendations for legislative and administrative actions. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can obtain necessary information from federal departments or agencies and use the United States mails for official purposes. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission will be compensated based on the Executive Schedule level IV rate for each day of duty. Officers or employees of the US government serving on the Commission will not receive additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, will be provided at authorized rates for employees of agencies. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. They can also determine their compensation without adhering to specific regulations. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel with pay rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. Federal agencies must respond to Commission recommendations within 180 days. The Commission will terminate upon submitting its update. $3,000,000 is authorized for the Commission for fiscal years 2013 and 2014.
